verses.text: "Now will I arise," says the LORD. "Now will I be exalted; now will I be lifted up.
You conceive chaff, you give birth to straw; your breath is a fire that consumes you.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33
rsbNotes.text: 33:1–24 This sixth and final oracle of woe in chs. 28–33 is against Assyria. By focusing on Assyria’s defeat and Judah’s exaltation, the Lord, the King of Judah, is exalted.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:7–12
rsbNotes.text: 33:7–12 With all Judah’s false hopes gone (vv. 7–9), the Lord acts to destroy Assyria.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:10
rsbNotes.text: 33:10 Now. The time for divine intervention and the glorious establishment of His kingdom has arrived.

verses.text: The peoples will be burned as if to lime; like cut thornbushes they will be set ablaze."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:12
rsbNotes.text: 33:12 lime . . . thorns. These similes explain how completely Assyria will be destroyed (cf. 27:4; Amos 2:1).

verses.text: You who are far away, hear what I have done; you who are near, acknowledge my power!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:13
rsbNotes.text:
33:13 Hear . . . acknowledge. People will confess that God’s judgments in history are wise and powerful and submit to His sovereignty.

far off . . . near. See 57:19; these statements include every person, from whatever nation or tribe.

verses.text: The sinners in Zion are terrified; trembling grips the godless: "Who of us can dwell with the consuming fire? Who of us can dwell with everlasting burning?"

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:14
rsbNotes.text: 33:14 Who among us can dwell. This realization by sinners challenges them to repent and live in harmony with God’s holy presence (Ps. 15:1; 24:3).

verses.text: He who walks righteously and speaks what is right, who rejects gain from extortion and keeps his hand from accepting bribes, who stops his ears against plots of murder and shuts his eyes against contemplating evil-

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:15
rsbNotes.text:
33:15 walks . . . shuts his eyes. These phrases describe conduct of the godly (Ps. 1:1, 2; 15:2–5; 24:4; Gal. 5:22–25; Eph. 5:1; James 3:13–18).

bribe. See note 1:23.

verses.text: this is the man who will dwell on the heights, whose refuge will be the mountain fortress. His bread will be supplied, and water will not fail him.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:16
rsbNotes.text:
33:16 dwell on the heights. With God.

fortresses . . . water. He enjoys divine protection (cf. Ps. 18:1–3) and provision (49:10; 55:1, 2; 62:9; 65:13; contrast 30:20).

verses.text: Your eyes will see the king in his beauty and view a land that stretches afar.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:17
rsbNotes.text: 33:17 king. The arrival of God’s kingdom and Messiah is of greater splendor than any previous manifestation (32:1 note).

verses.text: In your thoughts you will ponder the former terror: "Where is that chief officer? Where is the one who took the revenue? Where is the officer in charge of the towers?"
You will see those arrogant people no more, those people of an obscure speech, with their strange, incomprehensible tongue.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:18–19
rsbNotes.text: 33:18, 19 terror . . . stammering. Isaiah describes the misery of exile from home and oppression by foreigners.

verses.text: Look upon Zion, the city of our festivals; your eyes will see Jerusalem, a peaceful abode, a tent that will not be moved; its stakes will never be pulled up, nor any of its ropes broken.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:20
rsbNotes.text: 33:20 tent . . . cords. The exile has ended. Jerusalem enjoys stability and prosperity (54:2; cf. Rev. 21:1–3).

verses.text: There the LORD will be our Mighty One. It will be like a place of broad rivers and streams. No galley with oars will ride them, no mighty ship will sail them.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:21
rsbNotes.text:
33:21 broad rivers and streams. God provides all the needs of the citizens of His kingdom (41:18; 48:18).

galley . . . majestic ship. The kingdoms of this world can no longer intimidate and harass God’s people.

verses.text: For the LORD is our judge, the LORD is our lawgiver, the LORD is our king; it is he who will save us.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:22
rsbNotes.text: 33:22 See notes 2:4; 12:2; cf. 44:6; 51:4; Ps. 46; 48; 96–99; Zeph. 3:15, 17.

verses.text: Your rigging hangs loose: The mast is not held secure, the sail is not spread. Then an abundance of spoils will be divided and even the lame will carry off plunder.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:23
rsbNotes.text: 33:23 Your cords . . . sail. The people of the Lord are compared to a drifting ship.

verses.text: No one living in Zion will say, "I am ill"; and the sins of those who dwell there will be forgiven.
Come near, you nations, and listen; pay attention, you peoples! Let the earth hear, and all that is in it, the world, and all that comes out of it!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 33:24
rsbNotes.text: 33:24 inhabitant . . . people who dwell. See note on v. 14.

verses.text: The LORD is angry with all nations; his wrath is upon all their armies. He will totally destroy them, he will give them over to slaughter.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:2
rsbNotes.text:
34:2 enraged . . . furious. See notes 5:25; 10:5.

devoted them to destruction . . . slaughter. They are consigned to destruction, as the Canaanites were (Josh. 6:17).

verses.text: Their slain will be thrown out, their dead bodies will send up a stench; the mountains will be soaked with their blood.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:3
rsbNotes.text: 34:3 blood. The blood of the slain will be so great it will create mud slides (v. 7). This is imagery of the day of the Lord on earth.

verses.text: All the stars of the heavens will be dissolved and the sky rolled up like a scroll; all the starry host will fall like withered leaves from the vine, like shriveled figs from the fig tree.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:4
rsbNotes.text: 34:4 roll up. See Heb. 1:10–12; 2 Pet. 3:12. As the Lord stretched out the heavens at creation (42:25), in the end He will roll them up (Mark 13:24, 25; Rev. 6:13).

verses.text: My sword has drunk its fill in the heavens; see, it descends in judgment on Edom, the people I have totally destroyed.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:5
rsbNotes.text:
34:5 descends. The Lord’s avenging sword moves from demolishing the pantheon of heaven to Edom in particular.

Edom. Here representing the nations (63:1–6; Ezek. 35; Obad. 10–14; cf. Rev. 18:2).

verses.text: The sword of the LORD is bathed in blood, it is covered with fat- the blood of lambs and goats, fat from the kidneys of rams. For the LORD has a sacrifice in Bozrah and a great slaughter in Edom.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:6
rsbNotes.text:
34:6 sword. See Rev. 19:15.

Bozrah. An important city in Edom 30 miles southeast of the Dead Sea.

verses.text: And the wild oxen will fall with them, the bull calves and the great bulls. Their land will be drenched with blood, and the dust will be soaked with fat.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:7
rsbNotes.text: 34:7 Wild oxen . . . mighty bulls. These terms refer to the Edomite leaders.

verses.text: For the LORD has a day of vengeance, a year of retribution, to uphold Zion's cause.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:8
rsbNotes.text: 34:8 day of vengeance. The day of the Lord is the time when the Lord establishes His kingdom on earth by delivering and glorifying His saints and by punishing the wicked and the oppressors of His children (2:11 note; 35:4; 59:17, 18; 61:2; 63:4).

verses.text: Edom's streams will be turned into pitch, her dust into burning sulfur; her land will become blazing pitch!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:9
rsbNotes.text: 34:9 pitch . . . burning pitch. Alluding to the fall of Sodom and Gomorrah (Gen. 19:24–28; Ps. 11:6; Jer. 49:17, 18; Rev. 14:10, 11).

verses.text: It will not be quenched night and day; its smoke will rise forever. From generation to generation it will lie desolate; no one will ever pass through it again.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:10
rsbNotes.text: 34:10 Night and day . . . generation to generation. God’s judgment is everlasting (66:24; Matt. 18:8, 9; 25:41, 46; Mark 9:43, 48).

verses.text: The desert owl and screech owl will possess it; the great owl and the raven will nest there. God will stretch out over Edom the measuring line of chaos and the plumb line of desolation.
Her nobles will have nothing there to be called a kingdom, all her princes will vanish away.
Thorns will overrun her citadels, nettles and brambles her strongholds. She will become a haunt for jackals, a home for owls.
Desert creatures will meet with hyenas, and wild goats will bleat to each other; there the night creatures will also repose and find for themselves places of rest.
The owl will nest there and lay eggs, she will hatch them, and care for her young under the shadow of her wings; there also the falcons will gather, each with its mate.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:11
rsbNotes.text: 34:11 confusion . . . emptiness. The same Hebrew words are rendered “without form and void” in Gen. 1:2. God has decreed the desolation of powers that oppose His order. He brings disorder on those who have wreaked havoc with His order.

verses.text: Look in the scroll of the LORD and read: None of these will be missing, not one will lack her mate. For it is his mouth that has given the order, and his Spirit will gather them together.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:16
rsbNotes.text: 34:16 book of the Lord. Probably the prophecy of vv. 1–15. The Spirit will see to it that what the Word announces is fulfilled.

verses.text: He allots their portions; his hand distributes them by measure. They will possess it forever and dwell there from generation to generation.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 34:17
rsbNotes.text: 34:17 cast the lot. As God distributed the Promised Land by lot (Josh. 18:10), so He has divided Edom among the unclean animals (v. 11).

verses.text: The desert and the parched land will be glad; the wilderness will rejoice and blossom. Like the crocus,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:1
rsbNotes.text: 35:1 wilderness. See note 40:3. The presence of God’s Spirit of restoration transforms nature and people, even when affected by this sinful world (32:15 note).

verses.text: it will burst into bloom; it will rejoice greatly and shout for joy. The glory of Lebanon will be given to it, the splendor of Carmel and Sharon; they will see the glory of the LORD, the splendor of our God.
Strengthen the feeble hands, steady the knees that give way;

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:2
rsbNotes.text: 35:2 our God. For the revelation of God’s kingdom, see notes 6:3; 33:17, 21.

verses.text: say to those with fearful hearts, "Be strong, do not fear; your God will come, he will come with vengeance; with divine retribution he will come to save you."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:4
rsbNotes.text:
35:4 fear not. This admonition often occurs as an assurance of deliverance from oppressors (7:4; 8:12 note; 10:24; 37:6; 41:10, 13; 43:5; 51:7).

vengeance . . . save. God will bring complete deliverance to the oppressed and establish justice on earth (34:8 note).

verses.text: Then will the eyes of the blind be opened and the ears of the deaf unstopped.
Then will the lame leap like a deer, and the mute tongue shout for joy. Water will gush forth in the wilderness and streams in the desert.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:5–6
rsbNotes.text:
35:5, 6 blind . . . mute. These transformations are evidences of a supernatural restoration and are associated with the ministry of Jesus (Matt. 11:2–6; 12:22; Mark 7:37; Luke 7:21, 22).

waters. See note 1:30.

verses.text: The burning sand will become a pool, the thirsty ground bubbling springs. In the haunts where jackals once lay, grass and reeds and papyrus will grow.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:7
rsbNotes.text: 35:7 reeds and rushes. This is in contrast to 19:5, 6.

verses.text: And a highway will be there; it will be called the Way of Holiness. The unclean will not journey on it; it will be for those who walk in that Way; wicked fools will not go about on it.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:8
rsbNotes.text:
35:8 highway. See note 11:16; 40:3; contrast 33:8.

Way of Holiness. Only those who have been cleansed and consecrated are privileged to walk on the road of salvation that leads to Zion (4:3 note).

verses.text: No lion will be there, nor will any ferocious beast get up on it; they will not be found there. But only the redeemed will walk there,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:9
rsbNotes.text: 35:9 lion . . . ravenous beast. Contrast 13:21, 22; 34:11–15.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:9–10
rsbNotes.text: 35:9, 10 redeemed . . . ransomed. These two Hebrew words often appear as parallels (Jer. 31:11; Hos. 13:14), and are almost synonymous. Both words are used to describe God’s deliverance of Israel from Egypt (Ex. 6:6; 13:15, where the word “redeemed” translates the word for “ransomed” here). They play an important role in Isaiah’s description of the future deliverance from the Exile as a new exodus (51:10, 11). The Lord is the “Redeemer” (41:14 and note; 49:26) who has forgiven Israel’s sins (44:22; Ps. 103:3, 4).

verses.text: and the ransomed of the LORD will return. They will enter Zion with singing; everlasting joy will crown their heads. Gladness and joy will overtake them, and sorrow and sighing will flee away.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 35:10
rsbNotes.text: 35:10 sorrow and sighing. See note 25:8. Cf. 51:11.

verses.text: In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah's reign, Sennacherib king of Assyria attacked all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36–39
rsbNotes.text: 36:1–39:8 This historical bridge between chs. 1–35 and 40–66 directly parallels 2 Kin. 18:13–20:19. It records the fulfillment of Isaiah’s predictions that the Lord would judge Judah by bringing the Assyrian army to the gates of Jerusalem and would then judge that proud army by destroying it there, preserving a faithful remnant in the city. Hezekiah’s faith contrasts with that of his father, Ahaz. Hezekiah by faith accepted a sign when confronted with illness (30:7, 8); Ahaz refused to ask for a sign (7:12).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:1
rsbNotes.text:
36:1 fourteenth year. About 701 b.c. Hezekiah ruled with his father Ahaz as co-regent from 729–715 b.c. and was sole king from 715–686 b.c. Some explain the “fourteenth” year as a copyist’s error for “twenty-fourth,” while others suggest that Isaiah is referring to the beginning of Hezekiah’s independent rule in 715 b.c.

Sennacherib. He was the king of Assyria from 705–681 b.c.

fortified cities. Sennacherib states in his annals that forty-six such cities were conquered during this campaign (2 Kin. 18:13 note).

verses.text: Then the king of Assyria sent his field commander with a large army from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. When the commander stopped at the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, on the road to the Washerman's Field,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:2
rsbNotes.text:
36:2 the Rabshakeh. He was the royal counselor for military affairs. According to 2 Kin. 18:17 the king also sent his “Tartan” (“commander in chief”; cf. Is. 20:1) and his “Rab-saris” (“chief officer”).

Lachish. This fortress town in the western hill country of Judah, guarded an important road that led into the highlands south of Jerusalem (Jer. 34:7).

great army. According to 37:36, 185,000 troops were killed in the siege of Jerusalem; the full army would have been much larger than that.

upper pool. Isaiah had met Ahaz there (7:3).

verses.text: Eliakim son of Hilkiah the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder went out to him.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:3
rsbNotes.text:
36:3 Eliakim . . . Shebna. See note 22:19.

Joah . . . recorder. He was an important office holder and the official spokesperson of the kings.

verses.text: The field commander said to them, "Tell Hezekiah, "'This is what the great king, the king of Assyria, says: On what are you basing this confidence of yours?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:4
rsbNotes.text: 36:4 great king. An official title of Assyrian kings equivalent to “emperor.” By contrast, Hezekiah is named without a title (vv. 13, 14).

verses.text: You say you have strategy and military strength-but you speak only empty words. On whom are you depending, that you rebel against me?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:5
rsbNotes.text: 36:5 In whom do you now trust. The challenge of loyalty to Assyria, other political powers, or to the Lord is the essential message of Isaiah (12:2 note).

verses.text: Look now, you are depending on Egypt, that splintered reed of a staff, which pierces a man's hand and wounds him if he leans on it! Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who depend on him.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:6
rsbNotes.text: 36:6 Egypt. Hezekiah had depended on Egypt for support (30:2, 6, 7, 13; 31:1, 3 and notes). But as Isaiah had said Egypt could never deliver Judah because she too was under divine judgment (19:1–15; 20:3–6).

verses.text: And if you say to me, "We are depending on the LORD our God"-isn't he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah removed, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, "You must worship before this altar"?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:7
rsbNotes.text:
36:7 high places and altars. Hezekiah had removed many pagan and idolatrous sites in Judah (2 Kin. 18:4; 2 Chr. 31:1), no doubt to the dismay and anger of many Judeans.

this altar. This charge focuses on the requirement to worship exclusively at the temple of Solomon.

verses.text: "'Come now, make a bargain with my master, the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses-if you can put riders on them!
How then can you repulse one officer of the least of my master's officials, even though you are depending on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:8
rsbNotes.text: 36:8 horses . . . riders. Judah did not have cavalry; Assyria did.

verses.text: Furthermore, have I come to attack and destroy this land without the LORD? The LORD himself told me to march against this country and destroy it.'"

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:10
rsbNotes.text: 36:10 The Lord said to me. He is trying to appeal to the religious people of Judah.

verses.text: Then Eliakim, Shebna and Joah said to the field commander, "Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, since we understand it. Don't speak to us in Hebrew in the hearing of the people on the wall."

But the commander replied, "Was it only to your master and you that my master sent me to say these things, and not to the men sitting on the wall-who, like you, will have to eat their own filth and drink their own urine?"
Then the commander stood and called out in Hebrew, "Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!
This is what the king says: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you. He cannot deliver you!

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:11
rsbNotes.text: 36:11 Aramaic. For many centuries Aramaic was the international language of diplomacy and commerce.

verses.text: Do not let Hezekiah persuade you to trust in the LORD when he says, 'The LORD will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.'

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:15
rsbNotes.text:
36:15 trust . . . deliver. These words testify to Hezekiah’s public expression of faith in God.

trust in the Lord. This theme has been at the heart of Isaiah’s preaching in chs. 7–35.

verses.text: "Do not listen to Hezekiah. This is what the king of Assyria says: Make peace with me and come out to me. Then every one of you will eat from his own vine and fig tree and drink water from his own cistern,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:16
rsbNotes.text:
36:16 Make your peace. Lit. “make a blessing” (text note). The Rabshakeh appeals for renewal of a political covenant with Assyria. In contrast, see 27:5.

eat . . . drink. He tempts them with food and drink (37:30 note) in the midst of a harsh siege (v. 12). The Assyrians project an ideal and happy life, but the Lord alone can fulfill what they promise.

verses.text: until I come and take you to a land like your own-a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.
"Do not let Hezekiah mislead you when he says, 'The LORD will deliver us.' Has the god of any nation ever delivered his land from the hand of the king of Assyria?
Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they rescued Samaria from my hand?
Who of all the gods of these countries has been able to save his land from me? How then can the LORD deliver Jerusalem from my hand?"
But the people remained silent and said nothing in reply, because the king had commanded, "Do not answer him."

Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah the palace administrator, Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder went to Hezekiah, with their clothes torn, and told him what the field commander had said.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 36:17
rsbNotes.text: 36:17 take you. The phrase reflects the Assyrian policy of exiling a rebellious population (cf. 2 Kin. 15:29).
